metadata.title: Evaluation of the durability of asphalt concrete modified with nanomaterials using the TEAGE aging method

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Construction and Building Materials
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate /conbui ldmat
Evaluation of the durability of asphalt concrete modified with nanomaterials using the TEAGE aging method
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.conbuildmat.2019.04.121 0950-0618/ 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
⇑ Corresponding author. E-mail addresses: joao.crucho@tecnico.ulisboa.pt (J.M.L. Crucho), jose.manuel. neves@tecnico.ulisboa.pt (J.M.C. Neves), capitao@isec.pt (S.D. Capitão), luispicadosantos@tecnico.ulisboa.pt (L.G. Picado-Santos).
João Miguel Lopes Crucho a,⇑, José Manuel Coelho das Neves a, Silvino Dias Capitão a,b, Luís Guilherme de Picado-Santos a
aCERIS, Instituto Superior Técnico, Universidade de Lisboa, Av. Rovisco Pais 1, 1049-001 Lisboa, Portugal b Instituto Politécnico de Coimbra, Instituto Superior de Engenharia de Coimbra, Rua Pedro Nunes, 3030-199 Coimbra, Portugal
h i g h l i g h t s
The modification of asphalt concrete with nanomaterials was studied. The nanomaterials used were: nanosilica, zero-valent nanoiron and nanoclay bentonite. For the simulation of aging due to environmental conditions the TEAGE method was used. Nanosilica and nanoclay modifications improved the aging resistance of the mixture. Nanosilica and nanoclay modifications enhanced performance under aged conditions.
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 30 October 2018 Received in revised form 25 January 2019 Accepted 15 April 2019
Keywords: Aging simulation Asphalt mixtures TEAGE Nanoclay Nanosilica Nanoiron
a b s t r a c t
Aging phenomenon has a key role in the deterioration of the asphalt mixtures performance. The modification of asphalt binders with nanomaterials that can retard the aging process can be of great interest for the paving industry. This study evaluates the durability of asphalt mixtures modified with three types of nanomaterials: nanosilica, nanoiron and nanoclay. The mixtures were conditioned to accelerated aging and tested for stiffness, fatigue and indirect tensile strength. After testing the mixtures, the binders were recovered and characterized. The results showed that the modifications with nanosilica and nanoclay improved the aging resistance of the mixture indicating enhanced durability.
2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Asphalt pavements serve the majority of the road networks. The increase in traffic and traffic loads observed over the years puts additional pressure on the traditional asphalt binders, which seem to no longer ensure satisfactory performance during the desired service life. The use of modified binders, generally with polymers, became more frequent. In recent years, the modification of the asphalt binder using nanomaterials revealed capacity to improve the mechanical performance of the asphalt mixture [1–3]. In addition, there is also an expectation that the use of nanomaterials may improve the durability of the asphalt mixture, or in different
words, enhance the resistance to aging [4]. The number of studies involving nanomodified mixtures is still limited, and there is also an important lack of studies regarding the performance over the service life, i.e. characterization under aged conditions, and the consequent evaluation of their durability. Amongst the nanomaterials, the nanoclays [5–18] and nanosilica [4,19–26] are the most studied materials for asphalt binders modification.
The studies on the modification of asphalt binders with nanosilica, standard silicon dioxide, found the following effects on the binder: decrease in penetration, increase in softening point, higher complex modulus and lower phase angle [22,26–28]. The modified binders presented better fatigue resistance in dynamic shear rheometer (DSR) tests [21,24]. Regarding the behavior under low temperature, some authors [21,23,26,27] found the modification to cause higher creep stiffness and lower creep rate (m-value) in bending beam rheometer (BBR) tests, indicating worst performance. Concerning asphalt mixtures, the modification with
nanosilica lead to higher Marshall stability, higher indirect tensile strength (ITS), improved water sensitivity, higher stiffness modulus and lower permanent deformation [4,20,21,25,29–33].
The modification of asphalt mixtures with nanosilica can be beneficial for improving the mixture aging resistance [4,21,22,26]. When properly dispersed, the presence of these nanoparticles can slow the polymer’s aging process [21]. Studies about the properties and rheology of modified asphalt binder found that the introduction of nanosilica improved the viscosity aging index and led to reductions in the rheology aging index and carbonyl index (evaluated using FTIR spectrums), indicating a delay in the oxidative aging process [22,26]. A study evaluating the effect of aging on a nanosilica modified mixture [4], concluded, from the computation of an aging index based on laboratory tests, that the long-term aging was reducing with the increase of nanosilica content.
Clays are naturally occurring layered mineral silicates. The nanometric dimension of the nanoclay is the thickness of its silicate layers of about 1–2 nm. Authors studying nanoclays, generally, focused on bentonite which is mostly constituted of montmorillonite (smectite group), pure montmorillonite (calcium or sodium montmorillonite) and organically modified clays. The variety of nanoclay materials and asphalt binders to be modified, standard or polymer modified, led to some variability in the obtained effects. Regarding the effects of the nanoclay modification on the properties of the asphalt binder, generally, authors report: reduction of penetration, increase in softening point, increase in viscosity, increase in complex shear modulus and decrease in phase angle [8,10,14,15,18,26,28,34–37]. The effects of the nanoclay modification on the performance of the asphalt mixture properties were: improved water sensitivity, higher stiffness modulus, better fatigue resistance and lower permanent deformation [7–9,12,13,17,30,38–40]. The modification of nanoclays with organic modifiers was justified by the expectation of obtaining exfoliated structures in the final modified binder, thus achieving higher performance improvements. The raw nanoclays, in their hydrophilic natural form, can be more difficult to disperse into the asphalt matrix and may form only intercalated structures [41]. Generally, the modified nanoclays caused higher effects on the modified binder, however, authors that studied asphalt binder modification with raw nanoclays also reported positive effects, occasionally even better than the modified nanoclays [15,16,18,35,42].
Several authors [14,18,42–46] already highlighted the potential of the nanoclays to enhance the aging resistance of the asphalt binders. Such effect can depend on the neat asphalt binder to be modified [47]. Studies regarding the aging of asphalt binders under rolling thin-film oven (RTFO), thin-film oven (TFO), pressure aging vessel (PAV) and ultraviolet (UV) radiation [14,43,44] found that the modifications with nanoclays lead to: lower viscosity aging index, higher retained penetration, lower softening point increment and higher ductility retention rate. Results of DSR tests also suggested that the presence of nanoclays effectively reduced the thermo-oxidative aging of the binder, as the nanoclay modified binders presented lower aging factor [42,45]. Zare-Shahabadi and coworkers [18] performed BBR tests on PAV-aged samples of neat and two modified asphalt binders, one with raw bentonite and other with organically-modified bentonite (obtained by ion exchange with octadecylammonium salt), and concluded that the first caused a decrease in creep stiffness and a increase in the mvalue, and the second caused a decrease in creep stiffness and also a decrease in the m-value. The authors suggest that the clay platelets prevented the oxidation of the asphalt matrix and volatilization of light oil molecules. A study about the effect of nanomaterials on aging and water sensitivity of asphalt mixtures found that the use of raw nanoclay improved water sensitivity
under all aging conditions, as well as presented better aging index based on the ITS results of unaged and aged specimens [39].
The zero-valent nanoiron, or nano zero-valent iron, is a ferrous powder of non-valent chain, mostly iron particles and iron oxides. The high reactivity and specific surface of these nanoparticles allowed their use in reduction technologies, as ground-water remediation and wastewater treatment [48,49]. The modification of asphalt binder with zero-valent nanoiron leads to lower penetration values and to an increase in softening point and viscosity [30]. Regarding the asphalt mixtures, the modification with nanoiron particularly enhanced water sensitivity [30,50]. The nanoiron modification also presented better affinity aggregatebinder and lower permanent deformation [30].
There is an expectation that the use of nanoironwill improve the aging resistance of the asphaltmixture. The nanoiron has a reducing activity and due to the high specific surface of the nanoparticles, it can rapidly oxidize to iron oxides thus reducing the effective concentration of dissolved oxygen in the asphalt mixture. The effects of the of the nanoironmodification on the aging of the asphalt mixture are still not clear. A study that conducted ITS tests in unaged and aged specimens found that the nanoiron modified mixture had aging index values slightly higher than the neat mixture [39]. Such results indicateworse aging resistance, nevertheless such conclusion based only in one specific test can be premature.
It can be concluded that the effects on mechanical performance and aging resistance will be dependent on the type of nanomaterial used in the asphalt binder modification. The aging phenomenon influences the chemistry and rheology of the asphalt binder, leading to a degradation of its properties [51]. The aging of the asphalt binder occurs mostly due to oxidation and volatilization of its components [52]. Concerning rheology, aging causes an increase in complex shear modulus and creep stiffness, and a decrease in phase angle and creep rate (m-value) [53–55]. The aged asphalt binder becomes stiffer and more brittle [56–58], presenting an increase in viscosity and softening point and a decrease in penetration [59]. The effect of aging on the asphalt mixtures is similar, leading to an increase of stiffness modulus and decrease of phase angle [60], thus, being associated with several pavement distresses, such as fatigue cracking, top-down cracking, aggregates’ stripping and raveling [60–62].
To evaluate in laboratory the aging of asphalt pavements, the simulation of aging in compacted asphalt mixtures would be preferable and more representative than the simulation of aging in the binder separately or in loose (uncompacted) asphalt mixture. The morphology of the compacted asphalt mixture, particularly the air-voids content, configuration and interconnectivity, have an important role in accelerating/retarding the aging process [63]. Regarding the field aging caused by environmental conditions, several authors already highlighted the importance of UV radiation [64–72] and moisture damage [73–76].
The objective of this study is to evaluate the influence of three different nanomodifications in durability and long-term performance of asphalt mixtures. The nanomaterials selected for this study were nanosilica, nanoiron (zero-valent iron) and nanoclay (hydrophilic bentonite). To simulate in laboratory the aging of the compacted asphalt mixture was used the Técnico accelerated aging (TEAGE), method that was described and compared with LTOA in Crucho et al., 2018 [77]. This method was tuned to simulate seven years of aging due to environmental conditions in Lisbon area. An experimental program was implemented to characterize the mechanical performance of the aged mixtures, including: stiffness, fatigue resistance, indirect tensile strength and characterization of the recovered binders. The obtained results were compared with the characterization of mechanical performance of the unaged mixtures published in a previous work of the authors [30]. To quantify the effects in durability, it was determined the
aging sensitivity of the obtained performance indicators and computed a global aging index.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials and sample preparation
sections.text:
To allow a proper comparison of results, the materials used in this study and the methods used for the production of the asphalt mixtures were the same that were used on the previous study about the mechanical performance of nanomodified asphalt concrete (AC) under unaged conditions [30]. Thus, the materials used in this study were: neat asphalt binder 35/50 penetration grade; granitic aggregates; limestone filler; and nanomaterials to modify the asphalt binder. The studied mixture corresponds to a gap-graded AC14 surf 35/50 according to the European normative EN 13108-1, which aggregate gradation is presented in Fig. 1.
The nanomaterials used in this study were: nanosilica (NSIL), zero-valent nanoiron (NZVI) and nanoclay bentonite (NCBT). The NSIL, is silicon dioxide, SiO2, has an average particle size of 70 nm, a specific surface of 64 m2/g and pH in the range of 6.5–7.5. The NZVI is mostly iron nanoparticles, Fe (65%–80%), and iron oxides, FeO and Fe3O4 (20%–35%). It has an average particle size of 50 nm, a specific surface higher than 25 m2/g and alkaline properties (pH from 11 to 12). The NCBT is hydrophilic bentonite, H2Al2O6Si, that has a nanometric dimension in the thickness of its silicate layers of about 1–2 nm and has a pH in the range of 6–9. The neat asphalt binder was modified using the dry blending method, as used in the previous study [30], that consists in adding the nanoparticles into the heated asphalt binder (at 160 C) and apply mechanical stirring at 2000 rpm during 60 min. To promptly evaluate the proper dispersion of the nanoparticles in the asphalt binder, the softening point temperature of samples collected from the top and bottom of the modified binder blend was compared. All modifications presented small differences (0.4 C, 2.3 C and 0.1 C, for nanosilica, nanoiron and nanoclay, respectively), thus, the mechanical stirring process was considered acceptable. Each nanomodified binder has 4% nanomaterial content (in mass of the final binder).
In total, four mixtures of the type AC14 were produced according with the binder being used: not modified (neat 35/50 asphalt binder); NSIL modified; NZVI modified; and NCBT modified. All the blends were produced using a laboratory mixer (EN 12697-35), considering a binder content of 4.5% and the mixing and compaction temperatures were 164 C and 154 C, respectively. The optimum binder content previously determined, 4.5%, was set for the neat AC14 using the Marshall method and then the same was considered in the production of all the other mixtures. This assumption allows a better evaluation of the effects of the nanomodifications as the binder type is the only variable. Cylindrical specimens (63.5 mm height and 101.5 mm diameter) were produced using the impact compactor applying 50 blows on each side (EN 12697-30). Prismatic specimens (5 cm 30 cm 40 cm) were produced using the roller compactor (EN 12697-33) and sawed into prismatic beams (5 cm 5 cm 40 cm). The produced mixtures presented similar properties: bulk density of 2.390 Mg/m3, 3.6% void content and 14% voids in mineral aggregate (VMA). After production, the compacted specimens were conditioned for accelerated aging simulation in TEAGE according to the described in the following section.

sections.heading: 2.2. Aging conditioning
sections.text:
The TEAGE method was used to simulate in laboratory the aging of the AC mixtures. This method aims to simulate aging due to the exposure to environmental conditions for a certain period of time, using available weather data of the service

Fig. 1. AC14 aggregate gradation.
location. In this study the data acquired by the weather station of Instituto Superior Técnico, located in Lisbon, was used to determine the total energy received due to solar radiation and precipitation. Lisbon receives an annual energy of 5.7 GJ/m2 due to solar radiation and has 40 days per year with precipitation higher than 5 mm. The TEAGE method proposes an equivalency between the energy received by solar radiation and the applied UV radiation, as well as between the number of days with precipitation higher than 5 mm, considered to be enough to cause some surface water flow, and the application of watering drying cycles.
The TEAGE prototype was tuned to simulate seven years of Lisbon environmental conditions. The prototype was set to apply UV radiation continuously during 30 days, with no rest periods, and a combination of four watering/drying cycles per day with 40 min immersion per cycle. The prototype also includes a group of cooling fans that continuously induce an air draft, preventing the specimens to reach temperatures higher than 60 C. A more detailed description of the TEAGE method and its effects can be found elsewhere [77].
The TEAGE prototype enables a more realistic simulation of the field aging due to environmental conditions and allows some equivalency between the conditioning process and field service age. The exposure to UV radiation and the water washing effect caused a visible change on the coloration of the asphalt mixtures (Fig. 2), similar to the observed in aged asphalt pavements. The method also induces an aging gradient through the depth of the specimen, being the top surface more severely aged than in-depth [77].

sections.heading: 2.3. Test methods
sections.text:
The main focus of the experimental study (Fig. 3) was to evaluate the mechanical performance of the neat and nanomodified AC mixtures after being subjected to accelerated aging in laboratory. The aged AC mixtures were tested for stiffness, fatigue resistance and indirect tensile strength. After the fatigue tests, the binders were recovered and tested for fundamental characterization: penetration and softening point. As the TEAGE conditioning causes an aging gradient in the depth of the specimens the binder recovery was performed in two different sections of the specimens (Fig. 4): top section, from the UV exposed surface till middle depth of the specimen; and base section, from middle-depth till bottom of the specimen. Toluene was the solvent used in the process of binder recovery.
The test methods were selected according to the current European standards (Table 1). The stiffness and fatigue resistance tests were conducted in the fourpoint bending beam equipment. The temperature selected for these tests was 20 C as it is a temperature fairly representative of the Portuguese in-service conditions and also commonly used in these type of tests [78]. The stiffness results are the average of 10 individual specimens per mixture. In the fatigue tests a total of 18 specimens per mixture were tested and the adopted failure criterion was a 50% reduction of the initial stiffness modulus determined at the 100th load cycle. The indirect tensile strength tests were also used to evaluate the water sensitivity by calculating the ITSR. ITSR is the ratio between the ITS of conditioned (wet) specimens, by immersion in water at 40 C for approximately 70 h (ITSwet), and the ITS
of unconditioned (dry) specimens (ITSdry). The ITS results are the average of at least three individual specimens per group.
To evaluate the effect of the nanomodifications on the aging resistance, the test results of the aged mixtures were compared with the test results of the mechanical performance obtained under unaged conditions published in a previous study of the authors [30]. This effect can be quantified by the variation that the experimental parameters suffered with the aging process regarding their initial (unaged) value.
The variation between unaged and aged conditions can be simply designated as aging sensitivity. A high aging sensitivity indicates that the aging process had a dramatic effect in that parameter. On the other hand, an aging sensitivity near zero indicates that the aging process had no effect in that parameter.

sections.heading: 3.1. Evaluation of binder behavior
sections.text:
Table 2 presents the results of penetration and softening point of the fresh and recovered binders. The samples designated as fresh binders were collected prior to the asphalt mixture production. The samples designated TEAGE-aged were recovered from the aged specimens following the fatigue tests, and according to the location scheme presented in Fig. 4.
As expected, the recovered binders presented lower penetration and higher softening point than the correspondent fresh binders. The hardening of the binder was caused by the processes of mixing, compaction and TEAGE aging. Also, as previously highlighted, the TEAGE method induces an aging gradient through the depth of the specimens, thus the binders recovered from the top sections were more severely aged than the binders recovered from the base section. Considering the average value (between top and base sections) of the aged specimens, the neat binder presented a 45% decrease in penetration and a 26% increase in softening point. The modification with nanosilica presented a 24% decrease in penetration and a 21% increase in softening point while the modifications with nanoiron and nanoclay behaved similarly to the neat binder. These results suggest that nanosilica modification is suffering less hardening effect, i.e. aging. Nevertheless, looking to the results of the fresh binders, if compared to the neat binder the nanosilica modification itself had already caused a considerable reduction in penetration and increase in softening point, thus it is not possible to immediately conclude that aging resistance is being improved.

sections.heading: 3.2.1. Stiffness
sections.text:
The stiffness modulus and the phase angle obtained from the stiffness tests are presented in Figs. 5 and 6, respectively. As expected, each aged mixture presented an increase in the stiffness modulus and a reduction in the phase angle if compared with the results of the correspondent unaged mixture. Under aged conditions, the modification with nanoiron presented the highest stiffness modulus across the entire frequency range, followed by the modifications with nanosilica and nanoclay, and finally, the neat AC presented the lowest stiffness modulus. Compared with the stiffness modulus of the neat AC, the increase observed in stiffness modulus of the nanomodified mixtures was dependent on the test frequency. At the lowest frequency (1 Hz) the increase in stiffness modulus were 10%, 16% and 6% for the modifications with nanosilica, nanoiron and nanoclay, respectively. At the highest frequency (30 Hz) the increase in stiffness modulus were 0%, 10% and 1% for the modifications with nanosilica, nanoiron and nanoclay, respectively. Concerning the phase angle, except some variation at the low frequencies, the modification with nanoclay presented values similar to the neat AC. The modifications with nanosilica and nanoiron presented similar phase angle across the frequency
range, showing a reduction if compared with the neat mixture of 9% at 1 Hz to 5% at 30 Hz.
To understand if the nanomodifications gave some contribution to aging resistance, the results of stiffness modulus and phase angle at unaged and aged conditions were compared and the aging sensitivity (variation of the parameter regarding its unaged value) was computed (Figs. 7 and 8). The positive or negative contribution of the nanomodifications is evaluated according the aging sensitivity of the neat AC that is considered as reference. The aging sensitivity of the neat AC and nanosilica were very similar, presenting fairly close values for both stiffness modulus and phase angle. The modification with nanoiron had the highest values in every parameter and frequency, clearly indicating that the aging resistance was not being improved. Nanoclay modification showed a higher aging sensitivity concerning the stiffness modulus but lower concerning the phase angle, thus the outcome is not obvious.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Fatigue
sections.text:
The aged mixtures presented worse fatigue resistance if compared with the fatigue resistance obtained under unaged conditions. As highlighted previously by the recovered binder tests and the mixtures stiffness tests, the aging process leads to the hardening of the asphalt binder, consequently, the asphalt mixture becomes stiffer and more brittle, thus a reduction of the fatigue
resistance was expected. Fig. 9 presents the fatigue lines plotted in a log-log space. The fatigue lines were drawn according to the regression described by Eq. (1):
e ¼ a Nb ð1Þ where e is the applied strain (lm/m), N is the number of loading cycles, a and b are the regression coefficients. Table 3 presents the fatigue complementary results: a and b – regression coefficients, e4 – the strain correspondent to a fatigue life of 104 cycles, e6 – the strain correspondent to a fatigue life of 106 cycles, the slope of the fatigue law, and R2 – coefficient of determination.
Under aged conditions, the nanoclay modification had the best performance, followed by the nanosilica modification, and finally the neat AC and nanoiron modification. At the higher strain, 350 lm/m, the neat, nanosilica and nanoiron presented very similar behavior. At the lower strain, 150 lm/m, compared to the neat AC, the modification with nanoiron presented a slightly worst fatigue resistance but nanosilica presented some improvement.
Concerning the parameter e6, that is frequently used to compare different mixtures, relatively to the neat AC, under aged conditions, the nanoiron had 3% reduction, while nanosilica and nanoclay pre-
sented 8% and 14% increase, respectively. Regarding aging sensitivity, the aging process caused a reduction of strains e4 and e6. The reduction of e6 was 15%, 11%, 20% and 9% for neat, nanosilica, nanoiron and nanoclay, respectively. The reduction of e4 was 24% for nanosilica, and more homogenous among neat, nanoiron and nanoclay, of 11%, 14% and 12%, respectively.
Considering as reference the aging sensitivity of the neat AC, the modification with nanoiron presented higher aging sensitivity on both, e4 and e6, indicating that the aging resistance was not being improved. On the other hand, particularly regarding lower strain levels, the modification with nanoclay presented lower aging sensitivity combined with longer fatigue life under unaged conditions. Although the effects were more moderate, similar conclusions can be withdrawn for the nanosilica modification.

sections.heading: 3.2.3. Indirect tensile strength
sections.text:
The effect of aging in the indirect tensile strength is presented in Table 4 where are shown the results of ITSdry, ITSwet and ITSR. Compared with the unaged specimens, the correspondent aged specimens presented higher ITS values. The ITS increases with the aging period because of the hardening experienced by the binders during the aging process [79]. This result is in good agreement with the findings of the characterization of the recovered binders and stiffness tests. The increase in ITS of the unconditioned specimens (ITSdry) was 59%, 27%, 75% and 23% for neat, nanosilica, nanoiron and nanoclay, respectively. The increase in ITS of thewater sensitivity conditioned specimens (ITSwet) was 69%, 36%, 54% and 42% for neat, nanosilica, nanoiron and nanoclay, respectively.
Regarding the ITSR, although some variations were observed, the aging process did not affect this ratio significantly. A figure around an increase of 10% was reached. However, sometimes it could happen a slight decrease in ITSR, much probably related with samples’ properties variation that induces more/less increase for ITS (dry and wet) figures and then a different trend for the ratio wet/dry. Nevertheless, the variations of ITSR caused by aging were complying with the repeatability criterion (approximately 15%) mentioned in EN 12697-12. For the cases of nanosilica and nanoclay, the increase in ITS caused by aging was smaller than the observed with the neat mixture – lower aging sensitivity, suggesting that some improvement in aging resistance has occurred.
Concerning the effect of the nanomodifications, the conclusions obtained with the unaged specimens are valid for the aged mixtures as well. Compared with the neat AC, the nanomodified mixtures presented higher ITSdry, ITSwet, and ITSR, either for unaged, either for aged specimens. Under aged conditions the mixture modified with nanosilica presented the highest ITSR, and also the highest ITSdry and ITSwet values, 27% and 56% higher than the neat AC, respectively. Similar trend was observed with the nanoiron and nanoclay modified mixtures, presenting higher ITSdry and ITSwet values, 15% and 37%, for nanoiron, and 12% and 31%, for nanoclay, respectively.

sections.heading: 3.3. Analysis of aging
sections.text:
The evaluation of the mechanical performance of the modified mixtures under unaged conditions was presented in a previous work [30], where the comparison of mechanical performance among different mixtures was done using the global performance index (GPI) suggested by Martinho et al., 2017 [80]. However, under aged conditions, the GPI is not adequate because some parameters (e.g. stiffness modulus and indirect tensile strength) suffer an increase in their values due to the hardening effect caused by aging, thus a higher aging sensitivity can be misunderstood as an improvement in performance.
The durability of an AC mixture is highly related to its aging sensitivity, thus, to give a better insight of the improvements
attained regarding aging resistance, a global aging index (GAI) is proposed. The GAI computes the equivalent to a weighted aging sensitivity. GAI is the weighted sum of the variations caused by aging in the selected parameters, Eq. (2).
GAIi ¼ X
j¼1;2;3 wj Pagedi;j Punagedi;j Punagedi;j 100
ð2Þ
Pi,j is the value of parameter j for the mixture i. The mixtures considered were: (1) neat, (2) nanosilica, (3) nanoiron and (4) nanoclay. The selected parameters were: (1) Sm – stiffness modulus at 10 Hz, (2) e6 – strain for one million cycles fatigue life and (3) ITS – indirect tensile strength. The parameters’ weights (wj) considered for GAI computation were: Sm 40%, e6 20% and ITS 40%. The selection of the parameters and attributed weights is qualitative and based on what was considered by the authors the most important aging effects on a surface course. In fact, it is believed that Sm and ITS represent very well together the most part (80% for the sum of the two parameters) of the rigidity increase due to aging of an asphalt concrete for the surface course, leaving for e6 the remaining representative part (20%) because, in a certain extent, it stands for the lack of flexibility related to aging. The higher the parameters’ variations caused by the aging process, the higher the GAI score. If the GAI score is low, near 0%, the mixture has suffered no change in the considered parameters, presenting virtually no loss in its initial performance. Fig. 10 presents the ranking obtained according to the GAI. The modifications with nanosilica and nan-
oclay presented the lowest aging sensitivity, followed by the neat AC and finally the nanoiron. As the nanoiron presents a GAI higher than the neat AC, the nanomodified mixture is more prone to aging.
The combination of GPI and GAI is useful to compare performance and durability among different mixtures. The qualitative nature of global indexes as the GPI or the GAI can have some influence on the outcome, for example, by adjusting the parameters’ weights or selecting a different set of parameters. For the studied mixtures, the effect was limited, as the relative ranking of the mixtures remained the same after conducting a sensitivity analysis on the chosen parameters’ weights. Fig. 11 presents a global analysis of the mixtures, considering the previously determined GPI [30] and GAI scores. The modification with nanosilica had the best result in both indexes, showing improved initial performance and indicating better durability. The modification with nanoclay presented a similar behavior, although, if compared with nanosilica, the improvement in initial performance was more modest. The modification with nanoiron presented an improvement in initial performance but worse durability, revealing to be not interesting for asphalt mixture modification.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
The paper has evaluated the durability of asphalt concrete modified with different nanomaterials: nanosilica, zero-valent nanoiron and nanoclay. The neat and nanomodified asphalt concrete mixtures were aged to an equivalent of seven years of exposure to environmental conditions in Lisbon area, using the TEAGE method [77]. An experimental study was performed to obtain a characterization of the mechanical performance of the mixtures under aged conditions. The aged mixtures were tested for stiffness, fatigue resistance and indirect tensile strength. The correspondent recovered binders were tested for penetration and softening point. The obtained results were compared with a previous study regarding the characterization of the same nanomodified mixtures under unaged (fresh) conditions, allowing the analysis of aging sensitivity and computation of a global aging index.
The following main conclusions are drawn from the laboratory study:
The aging process affected the performance of the mixtures provoking a hardening effect. All the aged mixtures presented a stiffer and more brittle behavior as highlighted by the determined test parameters that evolved as expected: increase in stiffness modulus, reduction in phase angle, reduction in fatigue resistance and increase in indirect tensile strength. The modification with nanosilica enhanced aging resistance and led to superior mechanical performance under aged conditions. This modification presented the lowest score in the global aging index (14% less compared with the neat AC). Regarding the mechanical performance under aged conditions, the modification with nanosilica had better results in all the tests: higher stiffness modulus, lower phase angle, higher fatigue resistance, higher ITS and better water sensitivity. The modification with zero-valent nanoiron presented higher aging sensitivity and limited effects regarding the mechanical performance under aged conditions. This modification had the highest global aging index (17% more compared with the neat AC), indicating inferior durability. Under aged conditions, this modification presented better performance in ITS and water sensitivity, consistent with the previously found under unaged conditions. Nevertheless, the fatigue resistance had worsened, possibly, partially explained by the abrupt increase of stiffness modulus observed. The modification with nanoclay enhanced aging resistance and presented improvements in the mechanical performance under aged conditions. Compared to the neat AC, this modification presented lower global aging index (11% less). Regarding the mechanical performance under aged conditions, the modification with nanoclay presented improvements in all tests: higher stiffness modulus, lower phase angle, higher fatigue resistance, higher ITS and better water sensitivity.
A global analysis of the mechanical performance and durability indicates that the modifications with nanosilica and nanoclay were adequate to improve the mechanical performance during service life and enhance aging resistance of the asphalt mixtures.
Conflict of interest
None.

This support is gratefully acknowledged. The authors would like to thank to meteo|Técnico for providing the weather data and to NANO IRON for supplying the zero-valent iron nanoparticles.

references.title: A review of advances of nanotechnology in asphalt mixtures

referenceMentions.context: In addition, there is also an expectation that the use of nanomaterials may improve the durability of the asphalt mixture, or in different words, enhance the resistance to aging [4].

When properly dispersed, the presence of these nanoparticles can slow the polymer’s aging process [21].

Studies about the properties and rheology of modified asphalt binder found that the introduction of nanosilica improved the viscosity aging index and led to reductions in the rheology aging index and carbonyl index (evaluated using FTIR spectrums), indicating a delay in the oxidative aging process [22,26].

Studies about the properties and rheology of modified asphalt binder found that the introduction of nanosilica improved the viscosity aging index and led to reductions in the rheology aging index and carbonyl index (evaluated using FTIR spectrums), indicating a delay in the oxidative aging process [22,26].

A study evaluating the effect of aging on a nanosilica modified mixture [4], concluded, from the computation of an aging index based on laboratory tests, that the long-term aging was reducing with the increase of nanosilica content.
The raw nanoclays, in their hydrophilic natural form, can be more difficult to disperse into the asphalt matrix and may form only intercalated structures [41].

Studies regarding the aging of asphalt binders under rolling thin-film oven (RTFO), thin-film oven (TFO), pressure aging vessel (PAV) and ultraviolet (UV) radiation [14,43,44] found that the modifications with nanoclays lead to: lower viscosity aging index, higher retained penetration, lower softening point increment and higher ductility retention rate.

Studies regarding the aging of asphalt binders under rolling thin-film oven (RTFO), thin-film oven (TFO), pressure aging vessel (PAV) and ultraviolet (UV) radiation [14,43,44] found that the modifications with nanoclays lead to: lower viscosity aging index, higher retained penetration, lower softening point increment and higher ductility retention rate.

Studies regarding the aging of asphalt binders under rolling thin-film oven (RTFO), thin-film oven (TFO), pressure aging vessel (PAV) and ultraviolet (UV) radiation [14,43,44] found that the modifications with nanoclays lead to: lower viscosity aging index, higher retained penetration, lower softening point increment and higher ductility retention rate.
Results of DSR tests also suggested that the presence of nanoclays effectively reduced the thermo-oxidative aging of the binder, as the nanoclay modified binders presented lower aging factor [42,45].
Results of DSR tests also suggested that the presence of nanoclays effectively reduced the thermo-oxidative aging of the binder, as the nanoclay modified binders presented lower aging factor [42,45].

Zare-Shahabadi and coworkers [18] performed BBR tests on PAV-aged samples of neat and two modified asphalt binders, one with raw bentonite and other with organically-modified bentonite (obtained by ion exchange with octadecylammonium salt), and concluded that the first caused a decrease in creep stiffness and a increase in the mvalue, and the second caused a decrease in creep stiffness and also a decrease in the m-value.

A study about the effect of nanomaterials on aging and water sensitivity of asphalt mixtures found that the use of raw nanoclay improved water sensitivity under all aging conditions, as well as presented better aging index based on the ITS results of unaged and aged specimens [39].

The nanoiron modification also presented better affinity aggregatebinder and lower permanent deformation [30].
A study that conducted ITS tests in unaged and aged specimens found that the nanoiron modified mixture had aging index values slightly higher than the neat mixture [39].
The aging phenomenon influences the chemistry and rheology of the asphalt binder, leading to a degradation of its properties [51].
The aging of the asphalt binder occurs mostly due to oxidation and volatilization of its components [52].

The effect of aging on the asphalt mixtures is similar, leading to an increase of stiffness modulus and decrease of phase angle [60], thus, being associated with several pavement distresses, such as fatigue cracking, top-down cracking, aggregates’ stripping and raveling [60–62].
The morphology of the compacted asphalt mixture, particularly the air-voids content, configuration and interconnectivity, have an important role in accelerating/retarding the aging process [63].
The obtained results were compared with the characterization of mechanical performance of the unaged mixtures published in a previous work of the authors [30].

To allow a proper comparison of results, the materials used in this study and the methods used for the production of the asphalt mixtures were the same that were used on the previous study about the mechanical performance of nanomodified asphalt concrete (AC) under unaged conditions [30].

The neat asphalt binder was modified using the dry blending method, as used in the previous study [30], that consists in adding the nanoparticles into the heated asphalt binder (at 160 C) and apply mechanical stirring at 2000 rpm during 60 min.

The evaluation of the mechanical performance of the modified mixtures under unaged conditions was presented in a previous work [30], where the comparison of mechanical performance among different mixtures was done using the global performance index (GPI) suggested by Martinho et al.

The neat and nanomodified asphalt concrete mixtures were aged to an equivalent of seven years of exposure to environmental conditions in Lisbon area, using the TEAGE method [77].

metadata.abstractText: Aging phenomenon has a key role in the deterioration of the asphalt mixtures performance. The modification of asphalt binders with nanomaterials that can retard the aging process can be of great interest for the paving industry. This study evaluates the durability of asphalt mixtures modified with three types of nanomaterials: nanosilica, nanoiron and nanoclay. The mixtures were conditioned to accelerated aging and tested for stiffness, fatigue and indirect tensile strength. After testing the mixtures, the binders were recovered and characterized. The results showed that the modifications with nanosilica and nanoclay improved the aging resistance of the mixture indicating enhanced durability. 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
